item.title: 3 reasons why sodium-ion batteries may dethrone lithium
item.description: Lithium-ion batteries have played a vital role in the development of electric vehicles and we love them for that. But at the same time, lithium is expensive to produce, unstable in high temperatures, and a finite resource whose mining often comes with supply chain problems.

item.title: The AGI hype train is hit heavy traffic and running out of steam
item.description: While futurists and fundraisers used to make bullish predictions about artificial general intelligence, they’ve become quieter lately. Peter Thiel — the tech billionaire and rumored vampire — says Silicon Valley big brains have lost enthusiasm for AGI.

item.title: Elements of Qurno Blog Theme
item.description: Lithium-ion batteries have played a vital role in the development of electric vehicles and we love them for that. But at the same time, lithium is expensive to produce, unstable in high temperatures, and a finite resource whose mining often comes with supply chain problems.

item.title: Creating an object that travels at 1% the speed of light?
item.description: Light is fast. In fact, it is the fastest thing that exists, and a law of the universe is that nothing can move faster than light. Light travels at 186,000 miles per second (300,000 kilometers per second) and can go from the Earth to the Moon in just over a second. Light can streak from Los Angeles to New York in less than the blink of an eye.

item.title: Everything you wanted to know about the metaverse
item.description: In the wake of Facebook rebranding as Meta, reflecting its focus on the “metaverse”, Microsoft has now announced it, too, will launch into this space.

item.title: Why everyone is talking about ‘green steel’ at COP26
item.description: Among the rhetoric of climate change bingo and platitudes, there’s a term I’ve been hearing a lot at COP26 this week — green steel. But what is it, why does it matter, and what does it actually mean for us, the consumers and end-users?

item.title: How to hire a developer straight out of bootcamp — without getting burned
item.description: There’s a worldwide talent shortage in software development, and nearly one-third of hiring managers have hired someone from a coding bootcamp to help fill the void. 72% say bootcamp graduates are just as good or better than other hires, but 28% feel they are not equipped to handle their jobs.

item.title: I work 5 hours a day, and I’ve never been more productive
item.description: Something’s very wrong with the traditional 9 to 5: it doesn’t work.

item.title: Why developers are so divided over WordPress
item.description: After seeing WordPress top the most dreaded platform on Stack Overflow’s Developer Survey for two years in a row (2019 and 2020), a few weeks ago we explored why developers hate using the CMS.

item.title: Gig startups want you to believe they can replace your job — don’t fall for it
item.description: That’s the message that should be implied — if not explicitly stated — to every applicant of every gig and creator marketplace during the vetting process.
